title: Fog, a satellite dish and sandwiches: A Portrait of Cricket – in pictures
description: Award-winning photographer Tom Shaw, who in the past spent 15 years as the photographer with the England men’s team, has turned his lens towards the lower leagues of the recreational game across the country and produced the photobook A Portrait of Cricket Continue reading...
author: Tom Shaw
excerpt: Award-winning photographer Tom Shaw, who in the past spent 15 years as the photographer with the England men’s team, turns his lens towards the lower leagues of the recreational game across the country
text: Lydd Cricket Club. Searching for the lost ball. This project is a portrait of the game of cricket from across the country. The cricketing landscape has been shaped over the years by the diaspora from cricket-playing nations across the world who have brought their own passions, styles and traditions to the game. The aim is to move the visual narrative along from being solely the rural, leafy bucolic village green and to meet the players, spectators, volunteers, ground staff and everyone else who make the game what it is today. A Portrait of Cricket is available to purchase through Tom Shaw’s website Bilaal of Bolton Deane and Derby Cricket Club. Everyone can relate to Bill, waiting in the rain, slight chill in the early season air as he waits to bat. Colin of 40 Cricket Club, which is one of the oldest wandering teams in the world. Their aim is to take cricket to the schools by offering fixtures for young cricketers to play against more experienced players, who are all over 40. It was the end of the cricket season and almost all games I had planned to shoot in Lancashire were rained off - so I headed over the Pennines past a lovely little club I have been to in previous years called Queensbury. It is reported to be the highest club in England, and as I headed up there into the thick fog, to my amazement the ground was being prepared for a game . Both teams needed points to get promotion, so the match went ahead, much to the annoyance of the umpire who kept saying how ridiculous the whole thing was as you couldn’t see one end of the pitch from the other! Tayaba of Bradford Park Avenue Cricket Club. Glasgow’s Bellahouston Park was the setting for this match for Galloway CC (who play all their home matches in Glasgow as it is just too far to teams to travel down to Galloway). I love this picture - cricket is about pairs, and at the drinks break they all drank at the same time, in pairs, with the pair of towers behind - and one lone gentleman looking a little forlorn. Winnington Park Cricket Club. This ground in Northwich is adjacent to the old ICI chemical works, and makes for a more unusual backdrop - a hint to the past with the many works teams who played cricket, some in their own dedicated leagues. A fielder takes a break during play at Hackney Cricket Club, lying over the boundary. Jer Lane Cricket Club. A lovely little ground packed between the houses in Bradford. The road, the houses and the garden frequently have sixes hit into them. Geoffrey Boycott once played here, as attested to his portrait hung up, like a shrine, in the dressing room. Tea - a ritual in club cricket, and Stoke Newington Cricket Club bring along all their own chairs and gazebo. Birmingham Cricket League - Perry Hall Park. Players tuck into a communal Biryani. Everyone takes it in turn to make the Biryani and it gets delivered at the change of innings. Again it is a kind of ritual, and everyone shares it. Perry Hall Park is amazing as there are 16 cricket pitches over the whole park, with hundreds of spectators and families watching, talking and arguing about dropped catches and LBW decisions. Max of Lydd Cricket Club. Max was playing in his first ever match, borrowed the clothes and wore his Nike Air Jordan trainers. He played really well, made a good score, and by all accounts is hooked on the game and still plays. I came across this lovely chap playing in Scotland. He is in his 80s, and still keeps wicket. He loves playing and doesn’t ever want to give up. He has kept wicket for over 50 years, shown in his hands which are all taped up. James of Queensbury Cricket Club. A cold, end of season game meant the players waiting to bat had to keep warm - an arms tucked in jumpers kind of day. Photograph: Tom Shaw Littleborough Lakeside Cricket Club. A ground that is virtually under the M62, with the adjoining rugby pitches used for a camp site. Rossie Priory Cricket Club. A delightful little club tucked away in Perthshire - with small changing rooms which meant everyone getting ready on the balcony. A foggy game at the top of the hill at Queensbury Cricket Club, an end of season clash with both sides needing the points so the captains played on regardless. Sandwiches, the lifeblood of club cricket. Nabila of Bradford Park Avenue Cricket Club. Knockin and Kinnerley Cricket Club - with a huge satellite dish in the adjacent field. Birmingham Cricket League. A team warms up together at Perry Hall Park. Players stretch each other at Leeds Caribbean Cricket Club. Cricket on Hackney Marshes. Kenneth of Handsworth Cricket Club, which is the spiritual home of the old Birmingham Commonwealth League from the 50s and 60s which nurtured talented players from the West Indian community - and the tradition continues today. Finn of Castleton Cricket Club. Hartlepool Power Station Cricket Club. This club is situated in the grounds of the Nuclear Power Station, and the bleak featureless landscape is a contrast to the usually leafy bucolic surroundings - but is just as beautiful.
